In  preparing  any  country  program  or  strategy,  financing  any  project,  or  by  making  any 
designation of or reference to a particular territory or geographic area in this document, the 
Asian Development Bank does not intend to make any judgments as to the legal or other status 
of any territory or area.

I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The  Welfare  Improvement  Strategy  for  2012–2015  outlines  the  Government  of 
Uzbekistan’s  vision for national  development and  its  program for  achieving  more  inclusive 
economic growth. The Rural Development Program (RDP) and the Rural Housing Scheme 
(RHS) are critical pillars of the strategy, which focuses on reducing urban–rural disparity by 
improving  rural  living  standards  and  increasing  rural  income  and  job  opportunities.  The 
government has requested the Asian Development Bank (ADB) to provide technical assistance 
(TA) to improve the capacity of local governments to deliver these programs effectively. The TA 
was discussed with the government during a mission in July 2012, and subsequently confirmed 
in a memorandum of understanding signed in November 2012. The design and monitoring 
framework is in Appendix 1.1 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  To  achieve  more  inclusive  economic  growth  in  accordance  with  the  Welfare 
Improvement Strategy and support implementation of the RDP and the RHS, local governments 
have been tasked with important roles. These include (i) preparing and implementing strategies 
for regional industrial development and investment promotion to create sustainable income and 
job opportunities, and (ii) identifying, prioritizing, and delivering effectively public infrastructure 
and social services to communities and local businesses. 
 
3.  Increasing  the  effectiveness  of  rural  development  through  wider  access  to 
information. To support the effective allocation of resources, local governments require access 
to district-specific social data and cross-sectoral information that will enable them to assess, 
identify, define, and prioritize community needs. Development priorities and resource allocations 
are centrally determined by the national ministries and line agencies on the basis of the data 
they  collect  and  analyze,  which  is  then  aggregated  in  accordance  with  sector-specific 
requirements.  While  an  extensive  government  information  and  communication  technology 
network has been established, data is not readily available to local governments. Information 
from each ministry needs to be available for shared access on the government portal, which 
serves  as  the  common  depository.  Access  to  such  information  can  be  restricted  to  the 
originating agency or to selected agencies, or can be open to the public. Tiered access system 
means  all  information  can  remain  secure  or  be  made  available  to  a  wider  audience,  as 
appropriate.   
 
4.  Improving  the  transparency  and  accountability  of  planning  and  resource 
allocation. Greater participation by local governments in planning and resource allocation will 
enable them to respond more effectively to the needs of communities, improve the coordination 
of  service  delivery,  and  increase  the  transparency  and  accountability  of  service  delivery 
agencies. It will also improve value for money and effectiveness of local government services. 
Local  governments  lack  the  analytical  tools  and  templates  needed  to  prepare  baseline 
assessments, examine cross-cutting issues, identify priority community needs, and improve 
performance  monitoring  of  agencies  responsible  for  delivering  industry  promotion  and  job 
creation programs, as well as community infrastructure and social services.  
 
5.  An approach has been piloted by the government with the support of the United Nations 
Development  Programme  in  two  regions––Jizzakh  and  Namangan. In  partnership  with  the 
Institute of Forecasting and Macroeconomic Research (IFMR), a participatory approach to local 
development  and  strategic  planning  was  developed,  involving  the  private  sector,

2   
nongovernment organizations, and civil society. Data requirements were defined and sourced, 
assessment  and  planning  templates  were  developed,  and  e-government  options  explored. 
Assessment and adaptive replication of the approach are the planned next steps. 
 
6.  Improving local government capacity for results-based service delivery. Extensive 
capacity building of local governments is required to strengthen the focus on needs and results 
in the delivery of public services. Capacity building will enable local governments to better 
assess  and  prioritize  community  needs,  profile  those  needs  to  responsible  agencies,  and 
strengthen coordination between district and regional governments and among executive and 
line ministries. Regional governments need to work closely with the Ministry of Economy (MOE), 
the Ministry of Finance, and respective line ministries to plan, finance, and implement public 
investment programs for the delivery of services. District governments, the government’s front 
line and public face, are accountable to communities for program and service delivery.  
 
7.  Better coordination will support a more effective use of resources. Under the RDP and 
RHS, regional and district governments have important coordination and oversight roles. For the 
RDP,  local  governments  coordinate  and  oversee  the  performance  of  diverse  government 
agencies  responsible  for  implementing  industry  promotion  and  job  creation  programs,  and 
delivering community services. For the RHS, local governments coordinate and oversee (i) the 
selection and approval of new or expanded residential sites, (ii) community design and planning, 
and (iii) access to and delivery of infrastructure and social services. Capacity development of 
local governments to ensure fair, transparent, and timely delivery of these services is critical to 
rural development and improving rural livelihoods. 
 
8.  Government coordination and key agencies. Extensive stakeholder consultations and 
capacity  development  of  key  ministries  and  agencies,  as  well  as  regional  and  district 
governments, are critical success factors. The ministries and agencies are: 
(i)  Ministry of Economy. The MOE has an important coordination role as the lead 
agency responsible for national and regional development, including national 
investment plans. The MOE also has overall responsibility for implementation of 
the RDP and RHS, overseeing local government inputs, and developing and 
implementing a results-based planning, monitoring, and reporting framework.  
 
(ii)  Institute of Forecasting and Macroeconomic Research. The IFMR reports to 
the Cabinet of Ministers and is mandated to analyze regional disparities and 
prepare  regional  development  plans,  support  improved  competitiveness  and 
inclusive economic growth, and accelerate private sector development and the 
creation of sustainable income and job opportunities. The IFMR will guide and 
support  the  development  of  a  series  of  forms  and  templates  to  be  used 
nationwide for regional and district planning and results-based monitoring and 
reporting.  
 
(iii)  Academy of State and Public Management. The Academy of State and Public 
Management (ASPM) is mandated to deliver training to government officials from 
all levels of government to strengthen public administration nationwide. It will 
ensure that curriculum development for results-based planning and reporting is 
fully integrated into local government training programs.2   
 
                                                
2  The ASPM offers specialized courses, certificate programs, and a master’s degree in public administration.

3 
(iv)  Uzinfocom.  Uzinfocom  is  a  technical  agency  responsible  for  managing  the 
government portal, and providing technical support for downloading, cataloguing 
for  easy  retrieval,  and  ensuring  the  information  security  of  all  e-government 
applications.  With  its  network  of  regional  offices  and  district  focal  points, 
Uzinfocom  will  also  deliver  operational  and  technical  information  technology 
support across the government.  
 
9.  The  TA  is  aligned  with  the  Uzbekistan  country  partnership  strategy,  2012–2016 
approved in September 2012,3 and is included in the country operations business plan, 2012–
2014.4 The  TA  advances  the  objectives  of  the  country  partnership  strategy  by  promoting 
governance,  institutional  improvement,  and  capacity  development.  The  United  Nations 
Development Programme and the World Bank both include in their programs a number of 
projects and technical support activities for local government capacity building and delivery of 
infrastructure and social services. Coordination will continue in order to ensure synergy. 
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
10.  The TA impact will be improved service delivery by local governments. The outcome will 
be improved results-based planning capacity for local governments in Uzbekistan. 
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
11.  The TA will have three outputs:  
(i)  Development of a local government results-based planning, monitoring, 
and  reporting  framework.  A  results-based  regional  and  district  planning 
framework will be developed by the IFMR in close coordination with the MOE and 
with  the  participation  of key  stakeholders (including  community-based  social, 
women, and youth organizations). The framework will improve the planning for 
regional industrial development and job creation, and increase transparency in 
the  prioritization  of  local  government  needs  and  investments  based  on 
measurable  results-based  targets.  Following  testing  and  pilot  implementation 
across representative regions, implementation will be rolled out nationwide. 
 
(ii)  Development  of  a  local  government  capacity  building  program. Training 
curricula  for  local  governments  for  results-based  planning,  monitoring,  and 
reporting will be developed in conjunction with the  ASPM and a network of 
regional institutes. The curricula will be finalized in close coordination with the 
IFMR and MOE, and integrated into the ASPM’s public administration graduate 
degree and other training programs.  
 
(iii)  Development of a shared government information portal to improve access 
to information and ensure more efficient allocation and use of government 
resources.  A  local  government  information  portal,  building  on  the  current 
government portal, will be developed to enable broader information sharing and 
access  to  disaggregated  regional  and  district  information.  The  portal  will  be 
developed on the existing information and communication technology networks 
maintained by the MOE, Statistics Office, Ministry of Labor, local governments,

and  other  relevant  agencies.  Sectoral  and  cross-cutting  information  will  be 
downloaded, with access classified by the originating agency.  
 
C.  Cost and Financing 
12.  The TA is estimated to cost $750,000, of which $680,000 will be financed on a grant 
basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-IV). The government will provide 
counterpart support in the form of staff, office space, logistics and meeting arrangements; 
access to appropriate data and information and communication technology services; and other 
in-kind contributions. The cost estimates and financing plan are in Appendix 2. 
 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
13.  The TA will be implemented over 36 months from January 2013 to December 2015. The 
MOE will be the executing agency, and the MOE, IFMR, ASPM and Uzinfocom will be the 
implementing agencies. The MOE will appoint a TA coordinator, who will coordinate with the TA 
consultant team for all outputs. 
14.  The TA will cover remuneration, travel, and per diem of consultants, as well as training, 
workshops,  and  miscellaneous  expenses.  Disbursements  under  the  TA  will  be  done  in 
accordance with ADB’s Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from 
time to time).  
 
15.  The TA will provide 104 person-months of consulting services: 14 person-months of 
international  and  90  person-months  of  national  consulting  support.  The  detailed  list  of 
consultants and outline terms of reference are provided in Appendix 3. A consulting firm will be 
engaged in accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended 
from time to time), using the quality- and cost-based selection method (80:20) and simplified 
technical proposals. 
 
16.  The  consultants  will  maintain  a  close  working  relationship  with  the  MOE  and  will 
regularly  discuss  project  progress  and  findings.  They  will  provide  inception  reports  and 
deliverables  consistent  with  the  design  and  monitoring  framework  activities,  outputs,  and 
delivery  dates.  All  their  reports  will  be  written  in  English.  Procurement  of  goods  will  be 
undertaken by the selected firm in accordance with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, as 
amended from time to time). 
 
17.  The TA will follow the monitoring and supervision procedures for an ADB-administered 
TA. The outputs of the TA will support policy dialogue, and be disseminated through workshops, 
the government’s portal, and ADB’s website. An evaluation of performance and outcomes will 
be carried out at the end of the TA and reflected in a TA completion report. 
 
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION  
 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $680,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of Uzbekistan for Strengthening Governance and Improving Local Government 
Capacity for Results-Based Service Delivery, and hereby reports this action to the Board.

8  Appendix 3 
OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
1.  The technical assistance (TA) will require 104 person-months of consulting services—14 
person-months  from  five  international  consultants,  and  90  person-months  from  national 
consultants. A consulting firm will be engaged following the quality- and cost-based method 
(80:20) and simplified technical proposals in accordance with the Asian Development Bank’s 
(ADB) Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to time). The firm 
inputs will be on an intermittent basis, responding to the government requirements and progress 
made during implementation. Procurement of goods under this TA will be undertaken by the 
selected firm in accordance with ADB’s Procurement Guidelines (2010, as amended from time 
to time). The TA will be implemented over 36 months commencing on 1 January 2013 and 
terminating on 31 December 2015. 
 
A.  Consulting Firm 
2.  The consulting firm will: 
(i)  assign a team leader to provide overall project management. This will include 
reporting on the status of activities to the ADB project officer, managing the 
national  consultants,  and  communicating  with  government  officials  and  other 
stakeholders; 
(ii)  develop a project plan through consultation with all stakeholders, including the 
ADB project officer and government officials, and other consultants; and 
(iii)  ensure timely completion of the activities and quality delivery of the outputs, as 
defined in the design and monitoring framework. 
 
B.  International Consultants 
3.  Results-based management advisor (team leader, 6 person-months, intermittent). The 
advisor will have an advanced degree in public administration or economics, and at least 10 
years  of  experience  in  public  management  and  results-based  delivery  of  public  services. 
Experience in local government management is preferred, along with a sound understanding of 
technical  issues  in  information  technology.  Working  experience  in  developing  countries, 
preferably in the Commonwealth of Independent States, is an advantage. The advisor will 
perform the following: 
(i)  review  all  relevant  government  documents  related  to  planning,  monitoring, 
evaluation, and reporting processes;  
(ii)  with the statistician, and in close consultation with the Institute of Forecasting and 
Macroeconomic  Research  (IFRM),  assess  data  being  collected  via  key 
government agencies, determine its security classification, and with respective 
government  agencies  discuss  options  for  it  to  be  filed  and  stored  in  a 
disaggregated format, with secure shared access; 
(iii)  with the information technology advisor and in close consultation with Uzinfocom, 
assess relevant government information technology systems, applications, and 
processes, and develop a framework for managing information and  ensuring 
secure shared access; 
(iv)  with the statistician, and in close consultation with the IFRM, design templates 
and other tools to enable the local governments to analyze data from government 
agencies; 
(v)  with the statistician, and in close consultation with the IFRM, develop planning, 
monitoring, and evaluation report templates and other performance and results-
based tools appropriate for local governments and other stakeholders;

Appendix 3  9 
(vi)  with the local government training advisor, and in close consultation with the 
Academy  of  State  and  Public  Management  (ASPM),  design  an  appropriate 
capacity building program for local governments to use the new results-based 
framework, and adapt the program so that it can be taught by the ASPM to local 
government officials as part of the ASPM’s own curriculum; 
(vii)  with the local government training advisor, provide any necessary training to the 
ASPM and network of regional institutes; and 
(viii)  provide guidance to national consultants. 
 
4.  Local  government  training  advisor  (3  person-months,  intermittent).  The  advisor 
should have an advanced degree in public administration, and at least 10 years of experience in 
developing  and  delivering  public  sector  capacity  building  programs.  Specific  experience  in 
training  in  results-based  management  approaches  is  desirable.  Working  experience  in 
developing countries, preferably in the Commonwealth of Independent States, is an advantage. 
The advisor will report to the ADB project officer, through the team leader, and will perform the 
following: 
(i)  lead the work in developing, piloting, and adapting the local government capacity 
building program for integration into the ASPM’s academic program; 
(ii)  provide any necessary training to the ASPM’s teaching staff and guide them on 
pragmatic teaching approaches for the course(s); and 
(iii)  provide guidance to the national consultants on this aspect of the TA. 
 
5.  Industry  development  and  investment  promotion  advisor  (1  person-month, 
intermittent). The advisor should have an advanced degree in economics or finance, and at 
least 10 years of experience in the design and implementation of industry and investment 
promotion,  and  job  creation  programs.  Experience  in  training  for  industry  and  investment 
promotion and job creation is particularly desirable. Working experience in developing countries, 
preferably in the Commonwealth of Independent States, is an advantage. The advisor will report 
to the ADB project officer, through the team leader, and will perform the following: 
(i)  undertake  a  rapid  review  of  the  current  industry  development,  investment 
promotion,  and  job  creation  activities  at  the  national,  regional  and  local 
government levels; 
(ii)  with  the  IFMR,  design  a  framework  approach  for  regional  governments  to 
develop and implement an industry and investment promotion action plan; 
(iii)  with the IFMR, pilot an approach to develop and implement an industry and 
investment promotion action plan and a job creation program for specified pilot 
regions; 
(iv)  with the local government training advisor develop a training program for capacity 
building in developing and implementing an industry and investment promotion 
and job creation program; and 
(v)  provide guidance to the national consultants on this aspect of the TA.  
 
6.  Statistician  (1  person-month,  intermittent).  The  advisor  should  have  an  advanced 
degree  in  statistics,  and  at  least  10  years  of  experience  in  information  technology-based 
statistical  systems  and the  design  and  implementation  of  statistical frameworks to  support 
development. The advisor should also have experience in training on the use of statistical 
information for analytical purposes. Working experience in developing countries, preferably in 
the Commonwealth of Independent States, is an advantage. The advisor will report to the ADB 
project officer, through the team leader, and will perform the following: 
(i)  lead the review of government agencies to assess data sources, processes for 
data collection, aggregation, analysis, and storage and retrieval;

(ii)  with the team leader, and in close coordination with the IFMR and relevant 
government agencies, determine which data would best meet the requirements 
of local governments, and how this data should be stored for easy access and 
analysis; 
(iii)  with the information technology advisor, determine the best method to send data 
from  the  government  agencies  to  the  government  portal  and  enable  local 
governments to retrieve data from the portal; 
(iv)  with  the  local  government  training  advisor  develop  a  training  program  for 
pragmatic approaches for data collection, data analysis and interpretation, and 
performance and results-based monitoring, evaluation and reporting; and 
(v)  provide guidance to the national consultants on this aspect of the TA. 
 
7.  Information technology advisor (3 person-months, intermittent). The advisor should 
have an advanced degree in information technology, and at least 10 years of experience in the 
design  and  implementation  of  government  information  technology  systems,  and  a  sound 
technical  understanding  of  hardware  and  software  issues.  The  advisor  should  also  have 
experience  in  information  technology  training. Working  experience  in  developing  countries, 
preferably in the Commonwealth of Independent States, is an advantage. The advisor will report 
to the ADB project officer, through the team leader, and will perform the following: 
(i)  lead  the  work  associated  with  information  technology  assessments  of 
government agencies and local governments; 
(ii)  with the team leader and other advisors, determine the best method to transmit 
data from central government agencies to the government portal and enable 
local governments to access the data from the portal; 
(iii)  with the team leader and other advisors, ensure that template designs and other 
tools  for  results-based  reporting  are  user-friendly  and  optimized  for  data 
collection and analysis, and performance and results-based reporting; 
(iv)  advise on technical issues related to technical specifications for the IT software 
and hardware to be procured, and support the procurement process, particularly 
the assessment of bids; and 
(v)  provide guidance to the national consultants on this aspect of the TA. 
 
C.  National Consultants 
8.  In  addition  to  the  specific  terms  of  reference  below,  all  national  consultants  will               
(i)  support communication between government officials, the ADB project officer, the team 
leader, and other advisors for coordination of project activities; (ii) provide international advisors 
with  local  knowledge,  and  information  on  current  national  conditions,  policies,  and  other 
pertinent issues; (iii) help with the development of knowledge products and implementation of 
training  programs;  and  (iv)  provide  necessary  interpretation    and  translation  support  for 
meetings and documents relevant to the assignment. 
 
9.  Public  management  specialist (12 person-months, intermittent). The specialist will 
have  an  advanced  degree  in  public  management  or  economics,  and  at  least  8  years  of 
experience in public administration. Experience in working on results-based delivery of public 
services  is  preferred,  along  with  a  sound understanding  of technical  issues  in  information 
technology.  Excellent  written  and  spoken  English  is  required,  as  well  as  a  demonstrated 
capacity to work effectively in international teams to produce results. The public management 
specialist will work closely with the team leader in the following: 
(i)  act as deputy team leader and support the work of the entire team, including 
ensuring regular meetings, reporting, and results monitoring of all consultants;

Appendix 3  11 
(ii)  identify, collect, and help review all relevant government documents related to 
government planning, monitoring and evaluation, and reporting processes, and 
ensure that suitable translations are available got the entire team; 
(iii)  help design the new results framework, and assist team members and the ASPM 
in designing an appropriate capacity building program for local governments on 
the use of the new results-based framework;  
(iv)  facilitate the team’s work on data collection; assessment of current data types 
and  collection  methods;  security  assessments;  appropriate  options  for  local 
governments’  access  to  data,  and  its  storage and  use;  and  development of 
suitable  tools  for  local  governments  and  stakeholders  to  use  data  for  local 
planning and service delivery; and 
(v)  provide guidance to national consultants. 
 
10.  Local government training specialist (6 person-months, intermittent). The specialist 
should have an advanced degree in public administration, and at least 8 years of experience in 
public sector capacity building programs. The specialist will report to the team leader, work 
closely with other team members, and will perform the following: 
(i)  with the local government training advisor, design and pilot test curricula and 
train  the  trainers  for  the  results-based  local  government  capacity  building 
program, and its integration into the APA’s academic program; and 
(ii)  provide the ASPM with necessary training and guidance on pragmatic teaching 
approaches. 
 
11.  Industry  development  and  investment  promotion  specialist  (4  person-months, 
intermittent). The specialist should have an advanced degree in economics or finance, and at 
least  8  years  of  experience  in  the  design  and  implementation  of  industry  and  investment 
promotion programs that involve close consultation with industries and investors. The specialist 
will report perform the following: 
(i)  with the team leader, prepare a rapid review of the current industry development 
and investment promotion activities at the national and local government levels; 
and 
(ii)  with the team leader, and in close coordination with the IFMR, design and pilot a 
planning,  implementation,  and  performance  monitoring  framework  for  local 
governments to develop industries, attract investment, and foster job creation. 
 
12.  Statistician (4 person-months, intermittent). The specialist should have an advanced 
degree in statistics or relevant field, and at least 8 years of experience in the design and 
implementation  of  information  technology-based  statistical  frameworks  for  strategy 
development. The specialist will perform the following: 
(i)  with the statistical advisor, support the review of government agencies to assess 
processes for data analysis and collection, and data aggregation, storage, and 
retrieval; and 
(ii)  with the statistical advisor, and in close coordination with the IFMR and relevant 
government agencies, determine which data will best meet the requirements of 
local governments, and determine how this data should be stored and tagged for 
easy access and analysis. 
 
13.  Information  technology  specialist  (12  person-months,  intermittent).  The  specialist 
should have an advanced degree in information technology and at least 8 years of experience in 
the design and implementation of government information technology systems and information 
technology training. A sound technical understanding of both hardware and software issues is

12  Appendix 3 
 
 
required. With the information and technology advisor, the specialist will perform the following 
tasks: 
(i)  support information technology assessments of government agencies and local 
governments; 
(ii)  assist in developing template designs and other tools data entry, data analysis, 
that support results-based reporting; and 
(iii)  determine structural approaches to appropriately manage large volumes of data 
and  enabling  easy  and  time  efficient  online  access  for  data  input,  data 
processing, and publication. 
 
14.  Regional specialists (2 specialists for each of the 13 regions, 2 person-months per 
region, for a total of 26 person-months, intermittent). The specialists should have a degree in 
economics, statistics, or business, and 2 to 5 years of government, industry, or other relevant 
experience. Information technology skills are required and training experience desirable. The 
specialists will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  with the team and the IFMR, develop and pilot test templates and tools for local 
government results-based planning, monitoring and evaluation, and reporting; 
and 
(ii)  with the team, ASPM, and network of regional training institutes, implement pilot 
training and pilot tests. 
 
15.  Regional assistants (2 assistants for each of the 13 regions, 2 person-months per 
region, for a total of 26 person-months, intermittent). The assistants should have a degree in 
economics, statistics, or business, and 1 to 3 years of government, industry, or other relevant 
experience. Information technology skills are required, and training experience desirable. The 
assistants mentored by the regional specialists will perform the following tasks: 
(i)  with the team and the IFMR, guided by the advisors and the regional specialists 
develop and pilot test templates and tools for local government results-based 
planning, monitoring and evaluation, and reporting; and 
(ii)  with the team, ASPA, and network of regional training institutes, develop training 
materials, train the trainers, and evaluate the training effectiveness.
